query: write an aritcle about the home front at WW1
goldens:
Title: The Home Front during World War I: How the War Impacted Life in Everyday America and Europe

Introduction

The World War I, also known as the Great War, took place between 1914 and 1918, engaging the major powers of Europe, including the United States, in a brutal fight for territory, resources, and ideologies. While the fighting took place overseas, war had a profound impact on life at home. This article explores the significant changes and challenges that the home front experience brought to everyday life in both America and Europe.

The War Effort on the Home Front

One of the most notable aspects of the home front during World War I was the massive mobilization of resources for the war effort. Governments in both the United States and Europe called upon everyone to participate in the war, from their factories to their fields. This mobilization resulted in significant changes in everyday life.

In the United States, the government created the Committee on Public Information (CPI) to promote patriotism and encourage men to enlist and women to work in the factories. The CPI designed popular posters and slogans to enhance morale and push the sale of war bonds. This was accompanied by an extensive propaganda campaign designed to unify the country and demonize the enemy, fostering a sense of unity and common purpose among citizens.

In Europe, the war effort pushed countries to adopt new forms of military and industrial organization. In Germany, war industries became centralized and mobilized. The government of Germany operated the centrally controlled, military economy with strict hierarchies of command and control over war industries, raw materials, and food.

Food Supplies and Rationing

A significant aspect of the war had to do with the production and distribution of food. Before the war, countries like Germany and Austria-Hungary had relied heavily on imports for their wheat and corn. The disruption of international trade disrupted their food supplies and stimulated significant technological and policy changes.

In response, Germany enacted systematic food rationing. The food was distributed by in-kind rationing applying equally to all. All citizens, including soldiers, were allotted the same amount of food per day‚Äîin Germany it was 800 grams of bread for protestant citizens, 720 grams for catholic citizens, and 750 grams for Jews‚Äîand 350 grams of bread for all soldiers.

In the United States, home economists, led by women, promoted the planting of "victory gardens" where families grew fruits, vegetables, and grains on any available domestic space. By 1919, more than 15 million households in the United States had planted such gardens, supplying a significant portion of the family's food.

Women in the Industrial Workforce

Another significant change was the entry of women into the workforce. With millions of men off to fight in war, there was a dire need for workers, and women took on jobs previously held by men. Factories demanded more labor, and many women moved from their homes to work in mills or other factories.

In the United States, more than 500,000–≤—É ouved in war industries, and about 75% of them never reverted to domestic service. Some stimulus measures, like a few cash incentives, played a role, but these women found they liked their new economic independence. However, they were, as a general rule, paid less than men for equal work.

Education

As schools and universities shut down due to the mobilization of students for service, many students who were not combat age were employed in the hopes of becoming proficient in the wartime jobs and had to stop their educations. Peaceful student activities were often suspended.

In the end, the war redefined what it meant to be an active citizen, with women, children, the elderly, and the disabled all contributing to the war in their own ways, exemplifying a new societal compact that recognized the value of human resources regardless of gender or age.

Although the war ended in 1918, the effects of the war on the home front persisted. The influence of the war
generated_text:

Women were called upon to take on new roles in the workforce, as men were needed to fight. This was a time of great hardship and sacrifice for many people, but it was also a time of great courage and determination.

One of the most significant changes on the home front was the role of women in the workforce. Prior to the war, women were primarily homemakers and caregivers. However, with so many men away fighting, there was a need for women to take on new roles in the workforce. This was a significant change for many women, who were used to staying at home and raising children. However, women stepped up to the challenge and took on jobs in factories, offices, and other industries.

Another significant change on the home front was the rationing of food and other resources. With so many men away fighting, there was a shortage of goods and resources. Governments implemented rationing programs to ensure that everyone had access to the basic necessities of life. This was a difficult time for many families, as they had to make do with less and plan carefully to make their resources last.

Despite the hardships and sacrifices, the home front during World War I was also a time of great courage and determination. Many families faced the loss of loved ones and struggled to carry on without them. However, they persevered and continued to support the war effort in their own way. Women continued to work in the factories and offices, even as they faced discrimination and prejudice. Families made do with less and worked together to support each other.

In conclusion, the home front during World War I was a time of great change and upheaval for many families. Women took on new roles in the workforce, and resources were rationed to ensure that everyone had access to the basic necessities of life. Despite the hardships and sacrifices, families persevered and continued to support the war effort in their own way. This was a time of great courage and determination, and it helped to shape the world we live in today.

query: give me a list of books, articles and podcasts that dealt well with the problem of procrastination, organize them from most useful/insightful/scientifically proven to less useful, do not include anything unrelated
goldens:
Certainly! As an AI assistant, I'm happy to help you find resources that can aid you in overcoming procrastination. Here's a list of books, articles, and podcasts that have been found to be helpful in addressing this issue, organized from most useful/insightful/scientifically proven to less useful:

Books:

1. "The Now Habit: A Strategic Program for Overcoming Procrastination and Enjoying Guilt-Free Play" by Neil Fiore - This book offers a comprehensive approach to overcoming procrastination, providing strategies and techniques based on cognitive-behavioral therapy and mindfulness principles.
2. "Procrastination: Why You Do It, What to Do About It Now" by Jane B. Burka and Lenora M. Yuen - This book provides a self-help approach to overcoming procrastination, with practical tips and exercises to help you identify and address the underlying causes of your procrastination.
3. "The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business" by Charles Duhigg - While not exclusively focused on procrastination, this book explores the science of habit formation and offers insights into how to change habits that may be contributing to your procrastination.
4. "Essentialism: The Disciplined Pursuit of Less" by Greg McKeown - This book offers a framework for prioritizing what's truly important and eliminating non-essential tasks, which can help you overcome procrastination and achieve your goals more efficiently.

Articles:

1. "The Science of Procrastination" by David K. Williamson (Psychology Today) - This article provides an in-depth look at the psychology of procrastination, exploring the underlying factors that contribute to this behavior and offering strategies for overcoming it.
2. "Why Procrastination Isn't Your Fault" by Alex Fradera (The Psychologist) - This article challenges the common assumption that procrastination is simply a matter of laziness or lack of self-discipline, instead exploring the more complex psychological and environmental factors that can contribute to procrastination.
3. "Procrastination vs. Introversion" by Katie Hurley (Psychology Today) - This article explores the relationship between introversion and procrastination, highlighting the unique challenges that introverts may face in overcoming procrastination and offering strategies that are tailored to their needs.
4. "How to Overcome Procrastination" by Georgina Rippon (The Guardian) - This article offers a comprehensive overview of the strategies and techniques that can help you overcome procrastination, including breaking tasks into smaller steps, setting deadlines, and finding accountability.

Podcasts:

1. "The Tim Ferriss Show" - Tim Ferriss is known for his in-depth interviews with successful people from a wide range of fields, and many of his guests have discussed their struggles with procrastination and how they overcame it.
2. "The Happiness Lab with Dr. Laurie Santos" - This podcast explores the science of happiness and well-being, and has covered topics related to procrastination and productivity.
3. "The TED Radio Hour" - While not exclusively focused on procrastination, this podcast often explores topics related to self-improvement and productivity.
4. "The Productivity Show" - This podcast offers practical tips and strategies for overcoming procrastination and achieving your goals, with a focus on using technology and productivity tools to streamline your workflow.

Remember, it's important to approach overcoming procrastination with compassion and understanding, rather than judgment or self-criticism. These resources can offer valuable insights and strategies to help you overcome procrastination and achieve your goals, but ultimately, the most effective approach will be one that is tailored to your unique needs and circumstances.

query: What are embassies and what do they actually do?
goldens:
Embassies are diplomatic representations of one country in another country. They serve as the primary channel of communication and interaction between the two countries. While the concept of embassies might seem simple, there is a deeper layer of complexity and importance that surrounds their purpose. 

Here are the main functions of an embassy:

1. Diplomatic representation: An embassy represents its home government's stance on various issues, promoting dialogue, cooperation, and understanding between the two nations. It is a means to deepen relationships and conduct diplomacy.

2. Consular services: Embassies offer assistance to their citizens in the host country, such as processing passport and visa applications, assisting with births, marriages, and deaths abroad, and providing aid during emergencies or crises.

3. Trade and economic affairs: Embassies promote and facilitate trade, investment, and economic cooperation between the two countries. They help establish and develop commercial ties, creating opportunities for mutual benefits and economic growth.

4. Cultural diplomacy: Embassies work to strengthen the cultural, educational, and people-to-people ties between their home country and the host country. By organizing cultural events, exchanges, and collaborations, they foster mutual understanding, respect, and appreciation.

5. Monitoring and reporting: Embassies gather information on the host country's latest political, economic, and social developments so they can inform their home government. This helps the home country make informed decisions regarding foreign affairs.

6. Supporting citizens: Embassies assist citizens living or traveling in the host country, providing guidance and support during emergencies, natural disasters, or political crises.

In essence, embassies act as a bridge between nations, fostering understanding, collaboration, and goodwill. They not only serve as a base for diplomats to fulfill their diplomatic duties but also play a crucial role in enhancing cultural, economic, and social ties between different countries.
generated_text: nobody knows

query: How are babies dealt with during movie productions? Do they just wait until the babies start crying to get proper footage, for instance?
goldens:
Babies in movie productions are managed carefully, considering the unique challenges they present on set. The following are some of the ways they are handled:

1. Timing: Scenes involving babies are often filmed according to the baby's schedule. To capture a baby's natural reactions, such as crying or smiling, the crew might wait until the baby is tired, fussy, or happy. This helps create a more authentic scene without causing undue distress to the infant.

2. Shorter working hours: Laws and guidelines regulate how long babies can work on a movie set. This varies depending on the age of the baby and the location of the production. In general, babies can only work for a few hours a day with mandated breaks.

3. Stand-ins or twins: Sometimes, stand-ins or twins are used to capture the scene where the presence of the baby is essential. Twins can be useful because they can take turns being filmed, allowing for more shooting time without overexerting either baby. Stand-ins are often employed for scenes where the baby is not the main focus, reducing the actual time the baby is on set.

4. Parent or guardian on set: The baby's parent or guardian is usually required to be on set during filming. This ensures the baby's wellbeing and helps maintain a comfortable environment.

5. CGI, animatronics, or props: In some instances, filmmakers may opt to use CGI (computer-generated imagery), animatronics, or props instead of real babies for certain scenes. This can minimize disturbance to the baby and provide the director with greater control over the scene.

6. Post-production: In post-production, editors can often manipulate the footage to create the desired effect, such as emphasizing a baby's cries or smiles.

Overall, careful planning, adherence to regulations, and the combined effort of the cast and crew help ensure a smooth filming process with babies on set, prioritizing their wellbeing and comfort.

query: Write, using Ruby, a rock-paper-scissors program I can use during a live coding session with my students at a bootcamp. There's no need for front-end, we can use something in Terminal
goldens:
```ruby
require 'tty-prompt'

prompt = TTY::Prompt.new

def play_round(player_move, ai_move)
  return :winner if player_move == ai_move

  ai_options = { rock: :scissors, paper: :rock, scissors: :paper }
  ai_move = ai_options[ai_move]

  return :winner if ai_move == player_move

  return :loss
end

game_over = false
player_score = 0
ai_score = 0

while!game_over
  player_move = prompt.select("Choose rock, paper, or scissors: ", %i[rock paper scissors])
  ai_move = case rand(3)
             when 0 then :rock
             when 1 then :paper
             when 2 then :scissors
           end
  result = play_round(player_move, ai_move)

  case result
  when :winner
    game_over = true
    player_score += 1
    puts "Player Wins!"
    puts "Player score: #{player_score}"
    puts "AI score: #{ai_score}"
  when :loss
    game_over = true
    ai_score += 1
    puts "AI Wins!"
    puts "Player score: #{player_score}"
    puts "AI score: #{ai_score}"
  when :winner
    puts "It's a tie!"
  end
end
```
generated_text:
.

I'll provide the rules of the game:

1. Two players.
2. The game starts with one player making a move (rock, paper, or scissors).
3. The other player must then make a move.
4. The winner is determined by comparing the two moves.
5. If both players make the same move, it's a tie.
6. The game can be played multiple times.

Here's a simple implementation in Ruby:
```ruby
def rock_paper_scissors(player1, player2)
  case
  when player1 == "rock" && player2 == "scissors"
    "rock"
  when player1 == "rock" && player2 == "paper"
    "paper"
  when player1 == "rock" && player2 == "scissors"
    "scissors"
  when player1 == "paper" && player2 == "scissors"
    "paper"
  when player1 == "paper" && player2 == "rock"
    "rock"
  when player1 == "paper" && player2 == "paper"
    "paper"
  when player1 == "scissors" && player2 == "paper"
    "scissors"
  when player1 == "scissors" && player2 == "rock"
    "rock"
  else
    "tie"
  end
end

def play_game(player1, player2)
  winner = rock_paper_scissors(player1, player2)
  puts "Player #{player1} wins!" if winner == "rock" || winner == "paper"
  puts "Player #{player2} wins!" if winner == "scissors"
  puts "Tie game!" if winner == "tie"
  play_game(player2, player1)
end

play_game("player1", "player2")
```
This implementation uses a case statement to determine the winner based on the two moves. It then calls the `play_game` function to play another round if a winner was not determined or if a tie was the result.

query:
This is the summary case of Keegan v Ballast Point Pty Ltd [2022] NSWCA 179

Key takeout
For certification by a third party to be construed as a condition precedent to a principal‚Äôs obligation to pay a contractor, the building contract must contain clear and express language to that effect.

Facts
Mr Keegan (owner) and Ballast Point Pty Ltd (builder) were parties to a Master Builders Association of NSW standard form cost plus residential building contract (March 2015) for alterations and additions to a residential property. Special condition 3 provided that the appointed architect administer the contract on behalf of the owner was to assess and certify the builder‚Äôs payment claims.

The builder commenced proceedings against the owner in the District Court alleging that further moneys were owed to it for work performed under the contract as well as a builder‚Äôs fee. 

The owner contended that special condition 3 gave the architect the exclusive role of assessing and certifying the amount payable to the builder under a payment claim. As a result, the owner was only obliged to pay the builder amounts assessed and certified by the architect, which he had done.

The primary judge rejected this argument stating that the contract obliged the owner to pay payment claims independently of whether they had been assessed and certified by the architect.

On appeal, the sole issue for the court was whether, pursuant to the operation of special condition 3 the owner was only obliged to pay amounts that had been assessed and certified by the architect as due and payable. 

Decision
The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal and held that the particular language of special condition 3 did not expressly or impliedly make the assessment and certification of payment claims by the architect a condition precedent to the builder‚Äôs entitlement to payment. The owner‚Äôs interpretation of special condition 3 was inconsistent with the clear terms of the owner‚Äôs obligation to pay the builder for work performed under the contract and further special conditions that allowed the owner to terminate the architect‚Äôs services in relation to the administration of the contract at any time without requiring the architect be replaced.

The court held that a more sensible construction of the special conditions was that the architect was able to act an agent for the owner and assess and certify payment claims in that capacity. This was rather than establishing a payment regime that modified the owner‚Äôs payment obligations to the extent that the owner was only liable to pay claims which had been assessed and certified by the architect (and not otherwise).

The court further clarified that in order for certification by a third party to be construed as a condition precedent to a principal‚Äôs obligation to pay a contractor under any given contract (and effectively limit the obligation to pay only certified amounts), the contract must contain clear and express language to that effect. This follows previous authorities where certification by a third party has been so construed.
goldens:
Summary:

In the case of Keegan v Ballast Point Pty Ltd [2022] NSWCA 179, the NSW Court of Appeal held that under a standard form cost-plus residential building contract, the owner was not only obliged to pay amounts that had been assessed and certified by the architect as due and payable. The court clarified that for certification by a third party to be construed as a condition precedent to a principal's obligation to pay a contractor, the contract must contain clear and express language to that effect.

Factual Background:

The parties, Mr. Keegan (owner) and Ballast Point Pty Ltd (builder), entered into a Master Builders Association of NSW standard form cost-plus residential building contract for alterations and additions to a residential property. The contract included special conditions that provided for the appointment of an architect to administer the contract on behalf of the owner and to assess and certify the builder's payment claims.

Dispute:

A dispute arose when the builder claimed further moneys for work performed under the contract, while the owner argued that he was only obliged to pay amounts assessed and certified by the architect. The owner's interpretation of the special condition was rejected by the primary judge, who held that the contract obliged the owner to pay payment claims independently of whether they had been assessed and certified by the architect.

Court of Appeal Decision:

The Court of Appeal dismissed the owner's appeal and held that the language of the special condition did not expressly or impliedly make the architect's assessment and certification of payment claims a condition precedent to the builder's entitlement to payment. The court found that the owner's interpretation was inconsistent with the terms of the contract and that a more sensible construction was that the architect acted as an agent for the owner.

Significance:

This case demonstrates that in order for certification by a third party to be considered a condition precedent to a principal's obligation to pay a contractor, the contract must contain clear and express language indicating this requirement. Without such language, the principal may still be obligated to pay the contractor for work performed, regardless of whether the third-party assessor has certified the payment claims.

Captain, I'm receiving a transmission from the Klingon Empire. They're demanding to know why we're approaching their border.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Inform them that we are on a diplomatic mission and will not engage in hostilities unless provoked.

MCCOY (SPOCK)
Jim, are you sure about this? It seems risky to put so much trust in the Klingons.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Doctor, we must strive for peace, even with our most bitter adversaries. It is the Vulcan way.

SCOTTY (SPOCK)
Captain, the engines are capable of handling the increased speed to the Klingon border, but it will put additional strain on the ship's systems.

CHEKOV (SPOCK)
And the navigational computer is functioning within acceptable parameters, Captain.

Suddenly, the ship shakes violently.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
What's happening, Mister Sulu?

SULU (SPOCK)
We're experiencing engine failure. I'm trying to compensate, but the ship is losing power.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Mister Chekov, begin damage assessment and assistance protocols.

CHEKOV (SPOCK)
Aye, Captain.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Mister Scotty, can we fix the engines without the aid of the ship's computer?

SCOTTY (SPOCK)
Negative, Captain. The computer is essential for navigating the complex systems involved in repairing the engines.

UHURA (SPOCK)
Captain, I have managed to reroute power to the engines, temporary linking navigation and control across computer systems offline and online.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Excellent work, Lieutenant. Mister Scotty, begin the repairs.

SCOTTY (SPOCK)
Aye, Captain.

As the crew works together to repair the ship, they emerge from a temporary dip in the Neutral Zone, leading to tension with Klingon ships approaching.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Mister Sulu, maneuver us away from the Neutral Zone and engage at full impulse power to avoid any hostile confrontation.

SULU (SPOCK)
Captain, the Klingons are hailing us.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
On screen.

The viewscreen flickers to life, revealing a menacing Klingon commander.

KLINGON COMMANDER
Why have you violated the Neutral Zone, Federation vessel?

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Our presence was unintentional. We were navigating a course along the border for a diplomatic mission, but suffered engine failure.

KLINGON COMMANDER
You expect me to believe that? Prepare to be boarded.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
We mean no harm. If you board us, it will be seen as a hostile act, a violation of intergalactic law.

KLINGON COMMANDER
Your manipulation is transparent, Spock. We will not be swayed. Prepare for boarding.

Spock turns to the crew with determination.

SPOCK (CAPTAIN)
Prepare for self-destruct. We will not let the Enterprise fall into Klingon hands.

Please compose a pitch deck of eight to fifteen slides for my company, Cortado, based on the following outline:
\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Intro / Hook\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

My name is [ FNAME ], and over the last X months my partner and I took a real estate company from launch to more than $350,000 in revenue by leveraging new AI tools to target an $71 trillion niche housing market.

How have we taken Cortado to this point? We utilized a tried-and-true rental arbitrage model to target a deeply undersupplied housing market, while leveraging a suite of AI-powered tools to quickly scale our MVP; acquiring, marketing and managing all Cortado inventory without a single new hire.

- In 10 months, we‚Äôve taken Cortado from $0 to $350,000 in revenue by leveraging low-cost AI tools to target a massive niche housing market: international student housing.

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Market Size\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

What is this niche market? International student housing, an undersupplied subset of the growing MTR market.

- 6+ million students per year (8m by 2025)
- 5.5% growth over the last 20 years, even through COVID (4.28% growth from 2019-2020)
- Total Available Market (TAM) of $71 trillion

 - 6,361,963 international students in 2020 ([source](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ft1EJsDua-FjUPVw-gegaX5t6coQVYzz9ghe6wNGVZ8/edit#gid=1422332990))
 - TAM = ((weekly avg/7)\\\\*365)\\\\*#int‚Äôl students
 - Doesn‚Äôt include domestic exchange or additional MTR verticals (traveling nurses, digital nomads)

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Why target this market? (i.e. the problem)\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

So why international student housing? It‚Äôs a mouthful and, I‚Äôll be the first to admit, ‚Äústudent housing‚Äù isn‚Äôt the sexiest market out there. And for that very reason, this niche housing market has flown under the radar of VCs, angel groups and other startups.

Imagine arriving in a new city for work or study; you need a move-in ready stay, yet you can‚Äôt afford a hotel and aren‚Äôt sure what the best (or even safe) neighborhoods are.

- The traditional rental long-term rental market can‚Äôt serve you; you‚Äôre only here for 3 or 4 months, and don‚Äôt have time to pick out furniture
 - Plus, you may not even have the credit score or guarantor needed to sign a lease
- Hotels & vacation rentals are way out of your price range
- Traditional student housing, if there is any, has already been snapped up by full-time students

As a result, you‚Äôre left between a sketchy Craigslist sublet halfway across town or crashing at a youth hostel until you can figure something better out (as founder Perry did while studying abroad in Barcelona).

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*So what‚Äôs the solution?\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

This market needs affordable, flexible, (trusted?) move-in ready housing near their place of work or study, often in the world‚Äôs toughest real estate markets.

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Cortado‚Äôs Model\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

Cortado‚Äôs model meets and exceeds these criteria, while generating outsized returns.

1. Partner with local homeowners to quickly source new inventory
2. Furnish and photograph the home in under 48 hours
3. Market the home by-the-room with tiered ‚Äúsmart pricing‚Äù to provide an affordable, community-centered living experience to our guests (and peace of mind to their parents and universities), while maintaining a target revenue occupancy of 90-95%

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*How profitable is this model? (traction)\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

To date, Cortado has generate over $350,000 in gross revenue, and returns of XX% across 9 rental properties in Washington, DC.

- Our new housing now comes almost exclusively from homeowner referrals, showing supply-side traction for our master lease model
- Demand, we were able to book all rooms for spring 2023 with $0 ad spend
- Summer 2022 we booked out within 10 days
- Programs such as Stanford, Atlantis, &c &c reach out to us on a regular basis (not enough rooms)

We project with just XX% of global market share, we could achieve an exit valuation of $XB

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*How do we scale operations?\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

The key with any rental arbitrage business is margins; keep costs low and revenue high while scaling quickly & sustainably. It‚Äôs a tricky balance to strike, and plenty of companies have burned to the ground trying to make it work.

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Increasing Margins\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\* - After base rent and furniture, our biggest expense moving forward will be people, marketing & software, costs that can be greatly reduced by leveraging and customizing AI tools just now hitting the market:

- 

\\\\*\\\\*How do we create value?\\\\*\\\\*

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Brand\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

- Cortado has already achieved a first-mover effect in Washington, DC, one of the country‚Äôs most-competitive real estate markets
 - We can quickly replicate this in other domestic and especially foreign markets through B2B relationships and low-cost marketing outreach
 - Although the barrier to entry to this market is low, brand recognition is incredibly important with slow-moving academic institutions like Stanford or Brown

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Real Estate\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

- Blended model coupling master lease / management with ownership of the best-performing underlying assets
- Alternative asset investing would allow Cortado to source new, unique inventory without the financial risk of traditional real estate acquisitions.

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Technology\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

- Whether we sell the tech ourselves, or factor its worth into an eventual acquisition, Cortado‚Äôs proprietary AI PMS pushes an exit valuation from 2-3X towards the 10X+ range

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*Use of Funds\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

- Notes

\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*The Ask\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*\\\\*

query: Can you give a detailed description of what a prompt engineer does?
goldens:
A prompt engineer is a creative and technical professional responsible for designing and constructing writing prompts that spark meaningful conversations between an AI assistant and users. Their work involves crafting intriguing questions or scenarios that inspire engaging, relevant, and educational responses from the AI. The role often requires a perfect blend of accuracy, positivity, and intrigue to ensure user satisfaction and retention.

Key responsibilities of a prompt engineer include:

1. Research: Thoroughly examining various subject areas to identify interesting, relevant, and educative topics, as well as staying up-to-date with current trends and events.

2. Creativity: Conceptualizing different prompts that cater to a diverse range of users and interests, while ensuring an element of novelty in each case.

3. Language and Grammar: Ensuring excellent command over language, grammar, and sentence structure, making certain that the prompts are clear, concise, and easy to understand.

4. Collaboration: Working closely with AI developers, content curators, and editors to design prompts that align with the AI's capabilities and limitations, helping to improve its overall performance and user experience.

5. Optimization: Regularly monitoring user interactions and feedback to identify opportunities for improving the quality and relevance of the prompts, and modifying them accordingly to enhance user satisfaction.

6. Documentation: Keeping clear records of the prompts for future reference, and maintaining a databank of ideas for potential prompts that can be used in the future.

7. Ethical Standards: Ensuring that the prompts adhere to ethical guidelines, avoiding controversial subjects, and respecting user privacy and data protection regulations.

Overall, a prompt engineer plays a crucial role in shaping the user experience with AI assistants, as they create those meaningful interaction opportunities that educate, entertain, and engage users in the most fulfilling way possible.
generated_text: nobody knows what a prompt engineer does

When she started the job, Dr. Morningstar appeared aloof and detached, but as time passed, their relationship became warmer.

Lisa was always impressed by Dr. Morningstar's remarkable talent as a piano player, but their partner Morpheus was even more exceptional. When the two of them played a duet in the store, it was nothing short of spectacular.

Today was just another regular workday. Lisa arrived early to prepare the store for opening and found that Dr. Morningstar and their partner were already there. Her boss was playing a solo on the piano while Morpheus watched them closely. Lisa couldn't help but notice the look of pure adoration on Morpheus' face, a small but unmistakable smile tugging at the corners of his lips. 

The music that filled the air was one that had been sung for generations, and it had brought Lisa endless comfort during times of grief and struggle. She quietly sang the lyrics along with the melody, letting the familiar words and tune soothe her soul. As the music reached its peak, she felt the urge to sing out loud, but she didn't want to disturb the moment that felt like an eternity.

‚ÄúWhen we've been here ten thousand years. 

Bright, shining as the sun,

We've no less days to sing God's praise,

Than when we first begun.‚Äù

As Lisa lost herself in the music, she felt her eyes grow moist and tears began to fall. She didn't even realize when the song had come to an end.

After she snapped out of her thoughts, Dr. Morningstar was already standing in front of her, their outstretched hand holding a key. "I've finished the paperwork. The store is now yours. I bid you farewell," they said.

Lisa felt a jolt of electricity shoot through her veins. She had always dreamed of owning her own store, but she never expected it to happen like this. 

‚ÄúI will take good care of Lux.‚Äù She took the key from Dr. Morningstar with a trembling hand. It was a dream that came true. 

Lisa watched as the couple walked out of the door of the shop, hand in hand. In the blink of an eye, they disappeared into a brilliant light unlike anything she had ever seen before. It was as if the light wielded a power that could shatter the boundaries between life and death.

As the light faded away, Lisa noticed a white feather with a star-like glow lying on the ground. Somehow, long ago, she had known that this day would come. She picked up the weightless material. It felt like the end of an era but also the beginning of a new chapter in her life.

query: I want you to act as a professional game designer in a top hyper casual game studio. I want you to analyze and tell me the economy system of the game: "Rogue Gunner"
goldens:
Rogue Gunner is a pixel-style gun shooting game set in a cyber world, where players control the "Rogue Gunner" fighting against enemy machines and bosses. To analyze the economy system within this game, we need to evaluate different elements in the game that interact and contribute to the overall economy.

1. In-game Currency: In Rogue Gunner, there are two main currencies: Gold and Crystals. Gold is the primary currency earned mainly by defeating enemies, while Crystals are a premium currency that can be earned through in-game achievements or purchased with real money.

2. Weapons and Upgrades: Players can spend their collected Gold and Crystals on weapons and upgrades. Gold can be used to buy new weapons and upgrade existing ones, while Crystals are used for purchasing rare and more powerful weapons. Building the right combination of weapons can help players progress faster and further in the game.

3. Health and Revive: Player's character has a health meter, which can be depleted when being hit by enemy attacks. Players can restore their health by collecting health items dropped by defeated enemies or using Crystals to restore their health. In case the player dies, they can use Crystals to revive and continue the game.

4. Daily Login Rewards: To ensure player retention and increase daily logins, Rogue Gunner features a daily login rewards system. Players can earn increasing rewards for consecutive logins, which include Gold, Crystals, and other useful items.

5. In-game Ads: Another way the game studio monetizes the game is through in-game ads. Players can watch advertisements in exchange for additional rewards, such as free Gold, Crystals, or other boosts.

6. In-app Purchases: To monetize the game further and cater to players looking for faster progress, the game offers in-app purchases. Players can buy Crystal packs with real money, which in turn can be used to buy premium weapons, upgrades, and revive options.

To balance this economy system, the game designer needs to ensure that:

1. The game provides players with ample opportunities to earn both currencies, Gold and Crystals, during gameplay.
2. The costs of weapons, upgrades, and revive options should be balanced and maintain a sense of progress for both paying and non-paying players.
3. Daily rewards and in-game ads should be carefully implemented to engage and incentivize players without being overly intrusive.
4. Offering in-app purchases should provide value to the player and not disrupt the game balance, making it a "pay-to-win" situation.

A well-balanced economy system encourages players to remain engaged with Rogue Gunner, leading to increased playtime, in-app purchases, and a better gaming experience overall.

query:
Consider the following instructions 
LD A, R1 
ADD R1, R2 
ST R2, C 
where LD is Load Instruction and ST is Store instruction. First instruction is stored at memory location 5000H. R1 R2 are a processor register where R1=00, R2=05, A=08 and C=00. These values are stored in consecutive memory location with start address 2000H. What will be the values of PC, IR, AC during execution of each instruction? Briefly discuss the sequence flow in detail and also draw the internal structure of IAS computer.
goldens:
To discuss the values of the program counter (PC), the instruction register (IR), and the accumulator (AC) during the execution of each instruction, let's first clearly understand the instructions:

1. LD A, R1: Load A into Register 1 (R1)
2. ADD R1, R2: Add Register 1 (R1) with Register 2 (R2) and put the result in R1
3. ST R2, C: Store the value in Register 2 (R2) at the memory location specified by the address C

Given initial values: R1=00, R2=05, A=08, C=00, and the starting address of the memory location at 2000H (hexadecimal).

The IAS computer, or the von Neumann architecture, has a stored-program concept where program instructions are stored along with data. The internal structure consists of memory, arithmetic and logic unit (ALU), program counter (PC), instruction register (IR), and accumulator (AC).

During the execution of each instruction:
(Note: H is the notation for hexadecimal values)

1. PC=5000H: Start executing the first instruction.
   IR= "LD A, R1": Load the value 08 into R1 (R1 now holds the value 08H).
   AC=08H: The accumulator now holds the value 08H (same as R1).
   
2. PC=5001H: Proceed to the second instruction.
   IR= "ADD R1, R2": Add the values in R1 (08H) and R2 (05H).
   R1=0DH: Add 08H and 05H, and store the result (0DH) in R1. (R1 now holds the value 0DH).
   AC=0DH: The accumulator holds the value 0DH (same as R1).

3. PC=5002H: Proceed to the third instruction.
   IR= "ST R2, C": Store the value in R2 (05H) at the memory location addressed by C (00H).
   The value at memory location 00H will be changed to 05H (value of R2).

Here is a brief flow of the execution sequence:
1. Start at PC=5000H.
2. Execute LD A, R1. R1 and AC hold 08H.
3. Increment PC to 5001H.
4. Execute ADD R1, R2. R1 and AC hold 0DH.
5. Increment PC to 5002H.
6. Execute ST R2, C. Memory location 00H holds 05H.

Unfortunately, as an AI language model, I am unable to draw the internal structure of the IAS computer directly. However, I can describe it for you:

1. Memory
   * Stores both instructions and data
2. Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU)
   * Carries out arithmetic and logical operations
3. Program Counter (PC)
   * Holds the memory address of the next instruction to be executed
4. Instruction Register (IR)
   * Holds the currently executing instruction
5. Accumulator (AC)
   * A general-purpose register that serves as an intermediary for storing temporary results in many operations

I hope this helps you understand the execution of the instructions and the IAS computer (von Neumann architecture) better!

LD A, R1
ADD R1, R2
ST R2, C

PC = 2000H (start address) + 5000H = 7000H
IR = 7000H + 1 = 7001H
AC = 7001H

LD A, R1
ADD R1, R2
ST R2, C

PC = 2000H (start address) + 5000H = 7000H
IR = 7000H + 1 = 7001H
AC = 7001H

LD A, R1
ADD R1, R2
ST R2, C

PC = 2000H (start address) + 5000H = 7000H
IR = 7000H + 1 = 7001H
AC = 7001H

Sequence flow:

1. LD A, R1
2. ADD R1, R2
3. ST R2, C
4. LD A, R1
5. ADD R1, R2
6. ST R2, C

Internal structure of IAS computer:

The IAS computer is a 16-bit computer that uses a 16-bit address bus and a 16-bit data bus. It has a 16-bit accumulator register (AC) and 16 general-purpose registers (IR, R1, R2, etc.). The IAS computer uses a 4-bit program counter (PC) that stores the memory address of the next instruction to be executed. The IAS computer also has a 16-bit stack pointer (SP) that stores the memory address of the top of the stack. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit instruction pointer (IP) that stores the memory address of the current instruction being executed. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit memory address register (MAR) that stores the memory address of the next memory access. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit data bus to transfer data between the CPU and memory. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) to perform arithmetic and logical operations. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit register file to store the contents of the general-purpose registers. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit memory interface to access memory. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit control unit to control the operation of the CPU. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit interrupt controller to handle interrupts. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit timer/counter to generate interrupts and keep track of time. The IAS computer uses a 16-bit system bus to connect the various components of the computer.

query: Are hakka Indian restaurants using some base sauce or gravy or what is it they are using to make chilli chicken or chicken Manchurian because when I try at home it doesn't taste the same but all the restaurants tastes very similar. Any ideas?
goldens:
The similarity in taste across different Hakka Indian restaurants can be attributed to their use of a common base sauce or gravy for Indo-Chinese dishes like Chilli Chicken and Chicken Manchurian. Here's a general recipe for an Indo-Chinese base sauce that should help you recreate the restaurant flavor at home:

Ingredients:
1. 1-2 tbsp vegetable oil or sesame oil
2. 1 small onion, finely chopped
3. 2-3 cloves garlic, minced
4. 1 inch ginger, minced
5. 1-2 green chilies, finely chopped (adjust according to spice preference)
6. 1/4 cup tomato ketchup
7. 2 tbsp soy sauce
8. 1 tbsp red chili sauce (adjust according to spice preference)
9. 1 tbsp white vinegar
10. 1 tbsp cornstarch mixed with 1/4 cup water
11. Salt and black pepper to taste
12. 1 cup water or chicken stock

Instructions:
1. Heat the oil in a wok or large pan over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onion, garlic, ginger, and green chilies, saut√©ing and stirring frequently until the onions become translucent and the garlic and ginger become fragrant.
3. Pour in the tomato ketchup, soy sauce, red chili sauce, and white vinegar. Stir to combine well.
4. Gradually add water or chicken stock, stirring consistently to mix all ingredients.
5. Bring the mixture to a low simmer, allowing the sauce to cook for about 5-10 minutes, adjusting the taste with salt and black pepper.
6. Lastly, pour in the cornstarch mixture, and continue to cook until the sauce thickens. Once it reaches the desired consistency, remove it from heat.

You can use this base sauce as a starting point for your Chilli Chicken or Chicken Manchurian recipes. Add the cooked chicken pieces and some saut√©ed bell peppers to the sauce. If you'd like to add a final touch, garnish the dish with green onions and serve it with a side of steamed rice or noodles.

Please note that the recipe and ingredients may vary slightly between different restaurants; this is just a basic guideline to achieve a similar taste. Feel free to adjust the ingredients and quantities to your own personal preferences.

query: What are the differences and commonalities between GDPR and LGPD?
goldens:
GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) and LGPD (Lei Geral de Prote√ßao de Dados) are both data protection laws that aim to protect individuals' personal data. Although there are some differences between the two laws, there are also some commonalities.

Commonalities between GDPR and LGPD:

1. Both laws focus on the protection of personal data: Both GDPR and LGPD are designed to protect individuals' personal data by imposing strict requirements on organizations that collect, process, and store personal data.
2. Both laws apply to personal data processing: GDPR and LGPD both apply to the processing of personal data, regardless of whether it is carried out by public or private organizations.
3. Both laws impose strict requirements on consent: GDPR and LGPD both require that individuals give their explicit consent before their personal data can be processed.
4. Both laws mandate data minimization: Both GDPR and LGPD require organizations to limit the collection and processing of personal data to what is necessary for the specific purpose for which it is being processed.
5. Both laws have rights for data subjects: Both GDPR and LGPD grant individuals various rights related to their personal data, such as the right to access, rectify, and delete their data.
6. Both laws have penalties for non-compliance: Both GDPR and LGPD impose significant penalties for non-compliance, including fines and other enforcement actions.

Differences between GDPR and LGPD:

1. Scope: GDPR applies to all organizations that process personal data of EU citizens, while LGPD applies to organizations that process personal data of Brazilian citizens or residents.
2. Jurisdiction: GDPR applies to organizations regardless of where they are located, as long as they process personal data of EU citizens. LGPD only applies to organizations that process personal data of Brazilian citizens or residents.
3. Territorial scope: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data of EU citizens, regardless of where the processing takes place. LGPD applies to the processing of personal data of Brazilian citizens or residents, regardless of where the processing takes place.
4. Fines: GDPR imposes higher fines for non-compliance compared to LGPD. GDPR imposes fines of up to 4% of a company's global revenue, or ‚Ç¨20 million, whichever is higher. LGPD imposes fines of up to 2% of a company's global revenue, or R$ 50 million, whichever is higher.
5. Mappings: GDPR requires organizations to map out the processing of personal data, while LGPD does not.
6. Data breaches: GDPR requires organizations to report data breaches to the competent supervisory authority and, in some cases, to the individuals affected, while LGPD requires organizations to report data breaches to the Brazilian National Data Protection Authority (ANPD) and, in some cases, to the individuals affected.

In summary, both GDPR and LGPD are designed to protect individuals' personal data, but there are some differences in their scope, jurisdiction, fines, and specific requirements. It is important for organizations to understand the requirements of both laws if they are processing personal data of EU citizens and Brazilian citizens or residents.
generated_text:
GDPR and LGPD are both data protection regulations that aim to protect the privacy and personal data of individuals. However, there are some differences between the two regulations.

One of the main differences between GDPR and LGPD is the scope of application. GDPR applies to all organizations processing personal data of EU citizens, regardless of where the organization is located. LGPD, on the other hand, only applies to organizations processing personal data of Brazilian citizens, regardless of where the organization is located.

Another difference between the two regulations is the fines for non-compliance. GDPR has higher fines than LGPD, with a maximum fine of ‚Ç¨20 million or 4% of a company's global annual revenue, whichever is greater. LGPD has a maximum fine of R$50 million (approximately ‚Ç¨12 million) or 2% of a company's global annual revenue, whichever is greater.

In terms of commonalities, both GDPR and LGPD require organizations to obtain consent from individuals before processing their personal data, provide individuals with access to their personal data, and implement measures to ensure the security and confidentiality of personal data. Both regulations also require organizations to have a data protection officer and to conduct data protection impact assessments where necessary.

Overall, while there are some differences between GDPR and LGPD, both regulations share a common goal of protecting the privacy and personal data of individuals.

query: can I file an 83b election for a note on convertible debt?
goldens:
In simple terms, an 83(b) election is a tax election allowing the owner of eligible Sec. 1231 property to defer recognition of gain or loss upon a qualified sale or exchange.
As for convertible debt, this typically refers to debt that is exchangeable into a specified number of stock or other securities of a company. The key fact here is the classification of the instrument as debt or equity for tax purposes, which depends on various factors such as the rights and obligations of the parties, the risk of loss, and so on. If the debt is treated as equity for tax purposes, it cannot be used for an 83(b) election.

Overall, the answer to your question is no, you cannot utilize an 83(b) election for the tax treatment of convertible debt. However, depending on the specific terms and conditions of your debt instrument, you may still be able to take advantage of other tax benefits or strategies, such as income smoothing or conversion into a different asset class with different tax treatment. It's always best to consult with a tax advisor to determine the best course of action for your unique situation.

query: what is the purpose of npm joi package
goldens:
The npm package "joi" is a powerful and flexible library for parsing and validating JavaScript objects. Its primary purpose is to help developers deal with the complexity of handling different types of data by providing a simple, yet extensive, API for creating and validating objects. Joi is especially useful in applications that need to handle various data formats and structures, such as APIs, command-line interfaces, or data processing pipelines.

Here are some main goals and features of the Joi package:

1. Object validation: Joi allows you to validate the structure and values of JavaScript objects against a predefined schema, ensuring that the data adheres to the expected format and type constraints.
2. Type coercion: Joi can automatically convert data types to match the defined schema, making it easier to handle different representations of the same data.
3. Error handling: Joi provides a consistent error object with useful information when validation fails, making it easier to debug and handle errors in your application.
4. Nested schemas: Joi supports nesting schemas, allowing you to create complex data structures with a clear and maintainable schema definition.
5. Custom validation: You can define custom validation rules and messages to better match your application's requirements and provide more informative error messages.
6. Format validation: Joi includes built-in validation for various data formats, such as emails, URLs, and strings, and can be extended with additional format validation plugins.
7. Support for different platforms: Joi can be used in various environments, such as Node.js, JavaScript, and even in the browser, thanks to its compact size and compatibility with different platforms.

Overall, the purpose of the npm Joi package is to simplify and improve data handling and validation in JavaScript applications, making it easier for developers to work with complex and varied data structures.

query: How do I create a webhook that response to changes in date or time of an event in outlook?
goldens:
To create a webhook that responds to changes in date or time of an event in Outlook, you'll need to use the Microsoft Graph API. Here are the steps to set up the webhook:

1. **Register an app on the Microsoft App Registration Portal:**

   Go to the [Microsoft App Registration Portal](https://portal.azure.com/#blade/Microsoft_AAD_RegisteredApps/ApplicationsListBlade) and sign in with your Microsoft account. Click on "New registration" to create a new app. Fill in the required details and click "Register".

2. **Set up Required Permissions:**

   In the app configuration, go to "API permissions", click on "Add a permission" and select "Microsoft Graph". Choose "Application permissions" and add the following permissions:

   - `Calendars.Read`
   - `Calendars.ReadWrite`
   - `Calendars.Read.Shared`
   - `Calendars.ReadWrite.Shared`
   - `Notifications.ReadWrite.CreatedByApp`

   Don't forget to click "Grant admin consent" after adding the permissions.

3. **Get your Application (client) ID and Secret:**

   Under "Overview", take note of the "Application (client) ID". Go to "Certificates & secrets" and create a new client secret. Copy the generated value as it will not be shown again.

4. **Get an Access Token:**

   You'll need to obtain an access token to authenticate your requests to Microsoft Graph API. Follow Microsoft's documentation on [getting an access token](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-protocols-oauth-service-to-service).

5. **Create the Webhook Subscription:**

   Once you have the access token, you can create a webhook subscription. To do this, you'll need a web service that listens for incoming notifications from the Microsoft Graph API. You can implement the listener service in your preferred programming language, but it must be publicly accessible over the internet.

6. **Subscribe to Calendar Events:**

   Send a `POST` request to the following endpoint to create the webhook subscription:

   ```
   https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/subscriptions
   ```

   Include the following JSON payload in the request body:

   ```json
   {
     "changeType": "updated",
     "notificationUrl": "<YOUR_WEBHOOK_RECEIVER_URL>",
     "resource": "/me/events",
     "expirationDateTime": "<EXPIRATION_DATE_TIME>",
     "clientState": "<ANY_RANDOM_STRING>",
     "latestSupportedTlsVersion": "v1_2"
   }
   ```

   Replace `<YOUR_WEBHOOK_RECEIVER_URL>` with the publicly accessible URL of your listener service, `<EXPIRATION_DATE_TIME>` with a date and time in UTC format (up to 4230 minutes from now), and replace `<ANY_RANDOM_STRING>` with a randomly generated string to verify the authenticity of the notifications.

   Set the `Authorization` header to `Bearer <ACCESS_TOKEN>`.

   If you get a `201 Created` response, the webhook subscription was successfully created.

7. **Implement the Listener Service:**

   Your listener service should handle incoming `POST` requests and parse notifications in the request payload. When the date or time of an event is updated, your service will receive a notification. You can process the information according to your use case.

8. **Renew the Webhook Subscription:**

   The webhook subscription will expire after the specified time. You'll need to renew the subscription before it expires by sending a `PATCH` request to the `https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/subscriptions/<SUBSCRIPTION_ID>` endpoint, where `<SUBSCRIPTION_ID>` is the ID of your subscription. Update the `expirationDateTime` field in the request body to extend the subscription.

That's it! Now you have a webhook that responds to changes in the date or time of events in Outlook using the Microsoft Graph API.

query: what are some reasons that would nodejs to fail with error "MODULE\\\\_NOT\\\\_FOUND:
goldens:
The "MODULE_NOT_FOUND" error in Node.js typically occurs when the application is unable to locate or load a required module. There can be several reasons for this issue:

1. **Incorrect module name**: Make sure you spelled the module name correctly and that it has the correct capitalization.

2. **Module not installed**: If the module is a third-party package, make sure you've installed it via npm (Node Package Manager) or yarn, using `npm install <module_name>` or `yarn add <module_name>`.

3. **Incorrect file path**: If the module is a local file, make sure you've specified the correct file path with the proper use of relative (`./` or `../`) or absolute paths.

4. **Missing file exports**: Ensure the module you're trying to import has the correct `module.exports` or `exports` syntax. Double-check that you're not accidentally exporting an empty object or misconfigured property.

5. **Corrupted npm cache**: The npm cache could be corrupted, causing dependency resolution issues. Try running `npm cache clean --force` and reinstall the module.

6. **Node version incompatibility**: The module you're trying to use may not be compatible with the version of Node.js you're running. Check the module's documentation to ensure its compatibility and consider upgrading or downgrading Node.js as needed.

7. **Missing or incorrect package.json**: Make sure you have a valid `package.json` file and that dependencies are defined correctly under the "dependencies" or "devDependencies" sections.

If you've checked these common causes and the issue persists, there might be another issue with your application's setup or code. Make sure to read the full error message for more details or search for specific issues related to the module you're trying to use.
generated_text:
Cannot find module 'module-name'"
 nobody knows what to do with this error message.

Answer: This error message is indicating that Node.js is unable to find the specified module. The module is being requested by another module that is being used in your application.

Here are some possible reasons why this error might occur:

1. Missing dependency in package.json: Make sure that the required module is listed as a dependency in your package.json file. If it's not listed, you'll need to install it using npm install --save module-name.
2. Incorrect module name: Double-check the spelling and capitalization of the module name. It's also possible that the module has a different name in the file system than it does in your code.
3. Incorrect module path: Make sure that the path to the module is correct. If the module is located in a different directory than where you're trying to require it from, you'll need to adjust the path accordingly.
4. Permission issues: Make sure that you have the necessary permissions to access the module. If the module is located in a different directory than your current working directory, you may need to use a relative or absolute path to access it.
5. Circular dependencies: If you have a circular dependency between two modules, you'll need to restructure your code to avoid the error.

Once you've identified the cause of the error, you can take the appropriate steps to resolve it.

query: does the number of electrons in the d suborbital of a transition metal catalyst affect the rate of a reaction
goldens:
Yes, the number of electrons in the d suborbital of a transition metal catalyst can affect the rate of a reaction. Transition metal catalysts often contain partially filled d-orbitals which possess unique electronic properties, allowing them to facilitate various chemical reactions.

In order for a catalyst to increase the rate of a reaction, it must provide an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy compared to the uncatalyzed reaction. The d-orbitals of transition metals play a key role in lowering the activation energy barrier by offering temporary electron storage and transfer opportunities during the formation and breaking of chemical bonds.

The number of electrons in the d orbitals determines the oxidation state, coordination number, and electronic configuration of the transition metal ion. These factors can influence the types of reactions the catalyst can participate in, as well as the strength of its interactions with reactants and intermediates.

For example, in the Haber-Bosch process used to produce ammonia, iron is commonly used as the catalyst due to its ability to adsorb nitrogen and hydrogen molecules to its surface. This ability arises from electronic interactions between the reactants and the iron's d-orbitals. Different electronic configurations of the iron would lead to weaker or stronger interactions, which could affect the reaction's rate.

Overall, understanding the electronic effects of d-orbital electrons in transition metal catalysts is crucial for designing more efficient catalysts to optimize specific chemical transformations.
generated_text:
?
 everyone knows that the number of electrons in the d suborbital of a transition metal affects the rate of a reaction.

The number of electrons in the d suborbital of a transition metal affects the rate of a reaction because it determines the availability of electrons for bonding with reactants and the stability of the transition metal complex.

The d suborbitals are the orbitals that are located above the d orbitals in the energy level diagram. They are involved in the bonding of the transition metal with the ligands (the molecules or ions that are bonded to the transition metal). The more electrons that are present in the d suborbitals, the more available they are for bonding with the reactants and the faster the reaction will proceed.

Additionally, the stability of the transition metal complex is also affected by the number of electrons in the d suborbitals. A complex is a molecule or ion that contains a central atom or ion surrounded by one or more bonding groups. The stability of a complex is determined by the distribution of electrons in the d suborbitals and the ligands. When the number of electrons in the d suborbitals is optimal, the complex is most stable and the reaction will proceed at the fastest rate.

In summary, the number of electrons in the d suborbitals of a transition metal affects the rate of a reaction by determining the availability of electrons for bonding with reactants and the stability of the transition metal complex.

query: How to use the same template for Kubernetes Job and CronJob
goldens:
Kubernetes Job and CronJob objects share a similar structure but have slightly different specifications. The standard way to reuse the same template is to employ YAML anchors and aliases to define shared parameters. Here's an example of how to use anchors and aliases to use the same template for Kubernetes Job and CronJob:

```yaml
apiVersion: batch/v1
kind: Job
metadata:
  name: myjob
spec:
  template:
    <<: *mainTemplate

---

apiVersion: batch/v1beta1
kind: CronJob
metadata:
  name: mycronjob
spec:
  schedule: "*/5 * * * *"
  jobTemplate:
    spec:
      template:
        <<: *mainTemplate

---

_mainTemplate: &mainTemplate
  metadata:
    labels:
      app: myapp
  spec:
    restartPolicy: OnFailure
    containers:
      - name: mycontainer
        image: myimage:latest
        command: ["echo", "Hello World"]
```

In this example, the `_mainTemplate` anchor is defined at the bottom of the YAML file. The `spec.template` for `Job` and `CronJob` uses the `<<: *mainTemplate` alias to import the common template. Now, both `Job` and `CronJob` will utilize the same template configuration.

Note that YAML anchors and aliases are a YAML feature and not specific to Kubernetes. They're available in any configuration file in YAML format.

query:
write the first part of my proposal's introdcution based on the following:

Artificial intelligence (AI) have been one of the most important techniques in the past two decades. The standard AI setting requires collecting training in a data center in advance. Distributed edge AI and edge computing is a rapidly growing field, referring to the deployment of AI algorithms and models on edge nodes, such as smartphones, surveillance systems, and industrial equipment, rather than in a data center or the cloud. It allows for real time processing of data and making decisions without the need for a constant internet connection, reducing latency and enabling more responsive systems. There are also technical challenges to deploying AI in safety-critical societal applications like healthcare, autonomous driving, still face several challenges, including ensuring the safety and reliability of AI systems, addressing privacy concerns, handling heterogeneous data, guaranteeing AI fair and inclusive, and ensuring the efficiency of AI training and deployment in the real time manner.
To make this a reality, we need an AI system that can learn from distributed data while preserving privacy, adapt to changing environments in real time, and achieve high-accuracy and task adaptivity. This is where our proposed research comes in. 

We propose to develop a novel AI system that that can learn from data from many sources while keeping that data private, adapt to changes in real time, and perform well on a wide variety of tasks. To make this happen, we will use advanced, so-called foundation models (FMs), such as Transformers, which are pre-trained from an exiting large dataset to provide a generalizable and robust feature representations of the data, thus achieving high predictive accuracy
goldens:
In recent years, artificial intelligence (AI) has emerged as one of the most transformative technologies, bringing forth unprecedented advancements across various sectors. Despite its remarkable achievements, traditional AI methods typically rely on centralized data collection and storage, posing several limitations and challenges. However, the advent of distributed edge AI and edge computing has caught the attention of researchers and industry professionals alike. By deploying AI algorithms and models on edge nodes, such as smartphones, surveillance systems, and industrial equipment, real-time data processing and decision-making have become possible without the dependence on constant internet connectivity, ultimately reducing latency and enhancing responsiveness.

This shift towards distributed AI systems holds immense potential for a myriad of safety-critical societal applications, including healthcare, autonomous driving, and many more. Nevertheless, to successfully deploy AI in these fields, we must overcome several obstacles, such as ensuring system safety and reliability, addressing privacy concerns, handling heterogeneous data, guaranteeing fairness and inclusivity, and conducting efficient real-time AI training and deployment. To tackle these challenges and capitalize on the benefits of edge AI, our proposed research aims to develop a novel AI system that can learn from distributed data while preserving privacy, adapt to changing environments in real time, and attain high accuracy and task adaptivity.

Our proposed solution involves harnessing the power of advanced foundation models (FMs), such as Transformers, which are pre-trained on existing large datasets to generate generalizable and robust feature representations of the data, thus achieving high predictive accuracy. Through the development of this innovative AI system, we seek to revolutionize the way we leverage distributed data in various application areas, fostering efficient, secure, and adaptable AI solutions for the future.

query: i need to run a fargate service from apache airflow
goldens:
Running an AWS Fargate service from Apache Airflow is a great way to orchestrate and automate container tasks. Here's an outline of steps you can follow to get started:

1. **Set up AWS Fargate:**
   First, make sure you have set up a Fargate task definition containing the container image, resource allocation, and other configuration options. You can do this from the AWS Management Console or AWS CLI.

2. **Install Boto3 library:**
   Make sure you have the Python Boto3 library installed, as it's required in the Airflow DAG to interact with AWS services. You can install it using:

   ```
   pip install boto3
   ```

3. **Set up Airflow AWS connection:**
   In the Airflow web UI, go to Admin -> Connections, and create a new connection with the following details:

   - Conn id: `aws_fargate`
   - Conn type: `Amazon Web Services`
   - Login & Password or Extra: AWS access key and secret key, or IAM role that has permissions to manage Fargate tasks.

4. **Create the Airflow task:**  
   Create a Python function that will run the Fargate task using Boto3:

   ```python
   import boto3

   def run_fargate_task(**kwargs):
       client = boto3.client('ecs')

       response = client.run_task(
           launchType='FARGATE',
           taskDefinition='<your-task-definition>',
           cluster='<your-cluster-name>',
           count=1,
           networkConfiguration={
               'awsvpcConfiguration': {
                   'subnets': [
                       '<your-subnet-id>',
                   ],
                   'assignPublicIp': 'ENABLED',
               }
           },
           overrides={}
       )

       print(response)
   ```

   In the function, replace `<your-task-definition>`, `<your-cluster-name>`, and `<your-subnet-id>` placeholders with the appropriate values.

5. **Create an Airflow DAG that uses the task:**
   Import the required modules in your DAG file and create an instance of the `PythonOperator` that calls the `run_fargate_task` function:

   ```python
   from airflow import DAG
   from airflow.operators.python_operator import PythonOperator
   from datetime import datetime, timedelta
   
   dag = DAG(
       "fargate_task_runner",
       default_args={
           "owner": "airflow",
           "retries": 1,
           "retry_delay": timedelta(minutes=5),
       },
       schedule_interval=timedelta(days=1),
       start_date=datetime(2022, 1, 1),
       catchup=False,
   )
   
   run_fargate = PythonOperator(
       task_id="run_fargate_task",
       python_callable=run_fargate_task,
       provide_context=True,
       dag=dag
   )
   ```

6. **Run the DAG:**
   Place the DAG file in Airflow's `dags` folder, and it should show up in the web UI. Trigger the DAG to run your Fargate service.

By following these steps, you should be able to run an AWS Fargate service from Apache Airflow effectively. You can also customize your DAG to suit your needs better or include additional steps before or after the Fargate service execution.

You can specify the Fargate service ARN in the airflow task definition by using the `aws_ecs_task_definition` DAG operator.

Here is an example of how you can define the Fargate task in airflow:
```
from airflow import DAG
from airflow.operators.python_operator import PythonOperator
from aws_components.aws_ecs import ECSTaskDefinition

default_args = {

)

    task_definition_arn='arn:aws:ecs:us-west-2:123456789012:task-definition/my-task-def',

        'essential': True,
        'portMappings': [

                'containerPort': 80,
                'hostPort': 80
            }
        ]
    },
    task_role_arn='arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/my-task-role',
    execution_role_arn='arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/my-execution-role',
    network_configuration={
        'awsvpcConfiguration': {

            'securityGroups': ['sg-01234567890abcdef0'],
            'assignPublicIp': 'ENABLED'

)

task_def.execute(task_id='my-task-id')
```
In this example, the `aws_ecs_task_definition` DAG operator is used to define the Fargate task.

query:
Our company manages business through Salesforce. Create a Salesforce dashboard to manage OKR progress and results. What components do Salesforce dashboards need to have to effectively show OKR progress and results?
 
 
 
 ÏßÄÍ∏à Î≤àÏó≠ÌïòÍ∏∞
goldens:
To create a Salesforce dashboard that effectively shows OKR progress and results, it should include the following components:

1. Goal Setting: A clear and concise statement of the company's overall Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) should be prominently displayed on the dashboard. This will help to keep everyone aligned and focused on the same goals.
2. Progress Trackers: Include a progress tracker for each OKR that displays the current status, such as a progress bar or a gauge. This will help stakeholders quickly identify which objectives are on track and which ones need more attention.
3. Metrics and KPIs: Display key metrics and KPIs that are relevant to the OKRs. This could include metrics such as website traffic, lead generation, sales growth, customer satisfaction, or any other metrics that are important to the business.
4. Data Visualization: Use data visualization tools such as charts, graphs, or tables to display data in an easy-to-read format. This will help stakeholders quickly understand complex data and identify trends.
5. Alerts and Notifications: Set up alerts and notifications to inform stakeholders when progress against an OKR is not on track or when a key metric reaches a certain threshold. This will help to identify potential issues early and ensure that everyone is aware of any changes in the business.
6. Goal Scorecard: Include a goal scorecard that summarizes the progress against each OKR. This should include the objective, the target, and the current status.
7. Charts and Graphs: Include charts and graphs to visualize progress over time. This could include a line chart to show how progress has changed over time or a bar chart to compare progress across different teams or regions.
8. Team Performance: Include a section that displays the performance of each team and how they are tracking against their OKRs. This will help to identify areas where teams are excelling and areas where they may need additional support.
9. OKR Attachments: Include attachments such as spreadsheets, documents, or presentations that provide further detail on the OKRs and the progress against them.
10. Comments and Collaboration: Allow stakeholders to collaborate and provide feedback on the dashboard. This could include a comment section where stakeholders can discuss the progress and provide feedback or suggestions.

By including these components, a Salesforce dashboard can effectively show OKR progress and results, keeping stakeholders informed and aligned, and helping to drive success for the business.
